title: Properties of the Lambda(1405) Measured at CLAS

title_detail.value: Properties of the Lambda(1405) Measured at CLAS

summary:
Using the CLAS detector system in Hall B at Jefferson Lab, we have done a
high statistics measurement of the photoproduction of K+ Lambda(1405) using a
proton target. The reconstructed invariant mass seen in the various Sigma pi
decay modes has been measured, as well as the differential cross section
dsigma/dt. The nature of the Lambda(1405) with its peculiar mass distribution
is not well understood, and studies have shown that it may posess strong
dynamical components, which could be extracted from our data. Various aspects
of our analysis are discussed, as well as future prospects to further enhance
the precision of the results.

author: Reinhard Schumacher
arxiv_comment:
4 pages, 3 figures, for proceedings of "HYP-X", the 10th
  International Conference on Hypernuclear and Strange Particle Physics, to be
  submitted to Nuclear Physics A
fulltext:
Properties of the Λ(1405) Measured at CLAS
Kei Moriya and Reinhard Schumacher
for the CLAS collaboration

arXiv:0911.2705v1 [nucl-ex] 13 Nov 2009

Department of Physics, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, USA

Abstract
Using the CLAS detector system in Hall B at Jefferson Lab, we have done a high statistics measurement of the photoproduction of K + Λ(1405) using a proton target. The reconstructed invariant
mass seen in the various Σπ decay modes has been measured, as well as the differential cross section dσ
dt . The nature of the Λ(1405) with its peculiar mass distribution is not well understood, and
studies have shown that it may posess strong dynamical components, which could be extracted
from our data. Various aspects of our analysis are discussed, as well as future prospects to further
enhance the precision of the results.
Key words: hyperons, photoproduction, CLAS, Λ(1405)
PACS: 14.20.Jn, 25.20.Lj

1. Introduction
The Λ(1405) is a well-established hyperon resonance located just below NK threshold. Even
though its existence has been known since the 1960's and it holds a four-star rating in the
PDG [1], its nature as a resonance is not well understood. The Λ(1405) can only be seen
by reconstructing the invariant mass of the Σπ system into which it decays. Previous experiments [2, 3] have shown this mass distribution, or "lineshape" to be distorted from the usual
Breit-Wigner resonance form, leading to various speculations on the nature of the Λ(1405).
Using the CLAS [4] detector system in Hall B at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator
Laboratory, we have done a photoproduction measurement of the Λ(1405). Due to the high
statistics of the experiment and good resolution of the CLAS system, we were able to extract the
lineshapes and differential cross sections of the Λ(1405) in all three of its Σπ decay modes. The
lineshapes and cross sections will give a much improved quantitative description of the Λ(1405),
and will lead to further insights into its nature and production mechanism.
2. Theory of the Λ(1405) Mass Distribution
In recent years, theoretical progress in chiral dynamics in the S = −1 sector has gained much
attention, and has been extended to include a description of the Λ(1405). In this approach the
Λ(1405) is dynamically generated by iterating over the meson-baryon interactions among the
ground state baryon octet and psuedoscalar mesons octet. A paper by Nacher et al. [5] predicts,
using a chiral unitary approach, the lineshapes of the Λ(1405) as it decays to its three Σπ decay
modes. Figure 1 shows the predicted lineshapes, a result of the isospin 0 and 1 amplitudes
Preprint submitted to Nuclear Physics A

September 30, 2018

 Figure 1: Theoretical lineshapes predicted [5]
for the Λ(1405) using the chiral unitary approach. Due to the interfering isospin 0 and 1
terms, the lineshapes are distorted from a simple
Breit-Wigner form. In more recent years, attention has also focused on the possible two pole
structure of the Λ(1405) in the I = 0 channel
alone. This too is expected to influence the lineshapes [6].

interfering to produce shifts in the Σ+ π− and Σ− π+ lineshapes in opposite directions. Unlike an
ordinary resonance where the lineshape will follow a simple Breit-Wigner form, the Λ(1405)
spectrum is predicted to be strongly distorted due to a mixture of contributions. This figure
has been the starting point in our analysis, and our work has been focused on comparing our
experimental data with this prediction.
3. Data Analysis Using CLAS
In this section we show some of the work that was done at CLAS to study the photoproduction
of the Λ(1405). The reaction of interest at CLAS is γ + p → K + + Λ(1405), with the Λ(1405)
decaying exclusively into Σπ. The CLAS data set was obtained in 2004 using tagged real photons
up to 3.84 GeV, and a two charged track trigger. For the Σ+ π− decay mode, there are two possible
decays for the Σ+ , i.e. to pπ0 or n π+ . The first step of the analysis is to select either (p, K + , π− ) or
(K + , π+ , π− ) events.
After the three charged particles are selected and identified using momentum and TOF information, the missing mass of the event is calculated to obtain the missing particle(s). Figure 2(a)
shows an example of the missing mass squared (MM2 ) for one bin of our analysis. A Gaussian
fit to the neutron peak had a ±3σ cut applied. Next, we combine our final state particles to reconstruct the intermediate ground state hyperon that the reaction went through. In Figure 2(b) we
show the result of plotting the invariant masses squared of the (n, π+ ) versus (n, π− ). Again a fit
was done and a region of ±2σ was selected around each peak; the Σ overlap region was excluded
as well.
At this stage we are ready to fit our resulting Σπ spectrum as a sum of templates of Monte
Carlo (MC) spectra. The MC were initially generated with mass and width values given in the
PDG [1] and processed through the standard CLAS simulation package to account for detection
ineffeciencies. After this fitting process, the non-Λ(1405) contributions were subtracted off from
the data and the "residual" spectrum was taken to be from the Λ(1405). The resulting lineshape
was then acceptance corrected bin by bin in mass. The final lineshape spectrum was then obtained
by summing over all the production angle bins in each energy bin. Our final lineshapes are thus
shown this way, acceptance corrected and summed over all production angles.
Once the above process of fitting and obtaining the lineshapes in each energy bin was completed, the resulting lineshapes were then used as input to generate MC templates for the Λ(1405),
so that the process could be iterated and refined. The fit result in one sample bin is shown in Figure 3(a) for the iterated version.
2

 (a)

(b)

Figure 2: (Color online) (a) The missing mass squared (MM2 ) calculated for one energy and angle bin for the reaction
γ + p → K + + π+ + π− + X, where X denotes the missing particle(s). The neutron peak is clearly seen. The fit result
of a Gaussian (red line) and a polynomial background (green line) are also shown. The ±3σ range of the fit is shown
with the red dashed lines. (b) M 2 (n, π+ ) vs M 2 (n, π− ) for a particular bin when detecting K + , π+ , π− and reconstructing
the missing neutron. The horizontal band corresponds to Σ+ events, and the vertical band to Σ− events. A faint diagonal
band of neutral kaons decaying to π+ ,π− is also seen. ±2σ selection cuts are shown for each hyperon.

4. Results
After the iteration of the fit, the mass distribution we obtained is shown in Figure 3(b) for one
energy bin near threshold of the Λ(1405). Our lineshape result is shown for the three different
charge combinations Σ+ π− (red), Σ0 π0 (blue), and Σ− π+ (green). The Σ+ π− spectrum is a weighted
average of the two different decay channels of the Σ+ . The difference in the lineshapes is clear,
with the Σ+ π− spectrum peaking at the highest mass, and having a much sharper structure than
the Σ− π+ spectrum.
A comparison of our experimental result can be done with the theoretical prediction (Figure 1). Although the lineshapes differ from each other as predicted, we see that for the theory
prediction, the Σ− π+ spectrum is shifted toward the higher mass, whereas this applies to the Σ+ π−
spectrum in our experimental result. The difference in the two charged decay modes, according
to the theory, is based on an interference between isospin I = 0 and I = 1 terms, as shown in [5].
At the moment, this "interchange" of lineshapes is an unresolved issue that we hope to resolve
in future studies.
5. Future Prospects and Conclusion
The mass distributions of the Λ(1405) have been obtained in nine different energy bins, and
although much work has been put into obtaining these, there is still room for improvement. One
example of prospective work is using the kinematic fitter that was developed for CLAS. The
results shown here do not utilize the kinematic fitter, but our preliminary studies show that our
resolution is readily improved when using it.
Preliminary differential cross sections for the Λ(1405) were also shown during the presentation, which were obtained by summing over each lineshape in each energy and angle bin. The
values of this dσ
dt showed differences between the different charge combinations, not just in scale
but also in dependence on t. The nature of this different t-dependence for each decay mode is
unknown.

Figure 3: (Color online) (a) Sample of fit to M(Σπ) spectrum in one bin of the Σ+ → nπ+ decay mode. Only the heights
of the MC templates were allowed to change. The Σ(1385) yield was measured in the Λπ0 decay mode, and scaled by
branching ratio into the Σπ decay modes. This figure is for the iterated version of the fit, see text for details. (b) The final
Λ(1405) lineshape result that we obtained for one energy bin near threshold. The three different lineshapes are plotted
against each other. Stark differences are observed, especially between the two charged decay modes. The dashed line is
a relativistic Breit-Wigner shape using the nominal values of mass and width of the Λ(1405) given in the PDG. Notice
that although the Σ+ π− threshold is lower than that of Σ− π+ , the Σ− π+ spectrum appears at a lower mass.

Another prospect for our analysis is direct experimental evidence for the spin and parity of
−
the Λ(1405). Although the majority of theories assume J P = 21 , no direct experimental proof
for these quantum numbers has been given [7]. Our preliminary analysis shows a detectable
polarization for the Λ(1405), which is transferred to the Σ+ , allowing us to infer its spin and
parity. Our results are consistent with the common expectation, but will nontheless be an important step in identifying the nature of the Λ(1405). Also, it should be noted that from these
measurements the polarization of the Λ(1405) is measured, giving further information about its
production mechanism.
In conclusion, an overview of the CLAS analysis of the Λ(1405) has been given. We have
an unprecedented high statistics data set for the Λ(1405), and have obtained the lineshapes and
differential cross sections in energy bins spanning from threshold up to 2.84 GeV in the overall
center of mass energy. We observe a difference in the different decay mode lineshapes, leading
to a difference in the differential cross sections. We have just started comparing our results to
theory, and are eager to finalize our results in the coming months.

J. B. Westgard, Phys. Rev. Lett. 15, 224 (1965), which concluded that "spin greater than 12 is not required by our
+
data." J P = 21 is considered in O. Kittel et al., arXiv:hep-ph/0010186, arXiv:hep-ph/0508150.
